SCOPE
The EPA RMP regulation requires that an Executive Summary be provided as part of the registration submitted to the EPA. The following areas are addressed in this summary:
A?Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
A?Stationary Source Activities and Regulated Substances Handled
A?Worst-Case and Alternative-Case Release Scenarios
A?Prevention Program
A?Five-Year Accident History
A?Emergency Response Program
A?Planned Changes to Improve Safety

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
Central City Cooling is committed to complying with all of the regulatory requirements of the EPA Risk Management Program. Central City Cooling has developed their Risk Management Plan / Process Safety Management (RMP/PSM) making up the CalARP program to document policies and address the implementation of these regulations. The PSM sections pertain to the prevention of accidental releases and include the Process Hazard Analysis study and procedures for operating, training, maintenance, emergency response, and others. The RMP sections pertain to management systems and include the Hazard Assessment (Offsite Consequence Analysis) Report.

The RMP Prevention Program is equivalent to OSHA's Process Safety Management Program (PSM). The Prevention Program implemented by Central City Cooling is essential to help prevent or minimize the effects if a release occurs.

Federal regulations require reporting when there is a release of ammonia exceeding 100 pounds in 24 hours.

State regulations require reporting when there is an accidental release of ammonia or a threat of accidental release of ammonia.  Central City Cooling interprets this regulation at any release that poses a threat of injury above and beyond minor irritation to anyone.

All releases and near misses are to be recorded using the incident investigation forms.  All releases are to be monitored and all readings recorded.  All releases and near misses are to be reviewed to develop procedur

es that may prevent future incidents.

Any release of 25 ppm or more may result in immediately shutting down the ammonia system depending on the location of the release. Plant Managers are to be called if not on site for support.  Releases less than 25 PPM shall result in immediately notifying the shift supervisor and maintenance.

The facility utilizes CIM Electric to review refrigeration equipment integrity and safety on an ongoing basis and prior to initial or seasonal startup. These procedures identify potential sources of release and equipment corrections required to prevent these releases. CIM Electric, registered engineers and refrigeration experts review the equipment.

There are additional full time employees at this facility in addition to maintenance that have been trained to conduct visual and audible inspections of the ammonia systems during operation. They are instructed to report any condition that could result in an ammonia release immediately.  An example would be unusual noise, ammonia odor or equipment vibration. This team activity is the core of the prevention program.  


STATIONARY SOURCE ACTIVITIES AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED
The facility provides product cooling, and short-term storage for produce.

The facility is located in a rural area of Santa Barbara County East of Santa Maria. Ammonia is used as the refrigerant in the Plant Refrigeration System.  The ammonia inventory in this system exceeds the Federal and State thresholds.

The process is mostly a stationary system with some portable direct, closed loop mechanical refrigeration system components. The ammonia equipment is located both inside and outside of the building.

HAZARD ASSESSMENT
The regulation requires that the Worst-Case Release Scenario use the ammonia quantity in the largest vessel or pipe. As this system has interconnected piping the total system charge was used for the worst case scenario.

NOTE: It is important to consider that the Worst-Case Scenario is extremely u

nlikely to occur since this scenario does not consider any safety features of the system - in either design or operation. In addition the Main Plant System is separated by walls and distance. Furthermore as the refrigerant escapes pressure will decrease reducing the release rate. The scenario parameters are established by the regulation to provide uniformity for dialog between the industry, community, and regulatory agencies.

The regulation allows the facility to select the Alternate-Case Scenario.

PREVENTION PROGRAM
Central City Cooling's Prevention Program is described in the RMP/PSM Manual. The RMP Prevention Program is equivalent to OSHA's Process Safety Management Program (PSM). The Prevention Program implemented by Central City Cooling is essential to help prevent or minimize the effects if a release occurs.

Key objectives of Central City Cooling's Prevention Program are briefly described below:

1) Maintain current and complete refrigeration system technical information for operators. (Addressed under the Process Safety Information Element)

2) Require the equipment servicing partner provide thorough team evaluation of the refrigeration system.  The evaluation considers a number of potential problems including: mechanical problems, human errors, and external events (e.g., earthquakes).  All safety recommendations developed by the team are reviewed and addressed by Central City Cooling. (Addressed under Process Hazard Analysis and Maintenance Elements).

3) Written procedures and policies that establish how the refrigeration system should be operated and maintained and how to investigate accidental releases. (Addressed under Operating Procedures, Maintenance, and Incident Investigation Elements.) 

4) Certification of refrigeration operators to safely operate the refrigeration system. Central City Cooling certifies operators following completion of operator training and the company's confirmation of the operator's ability to apply what they have learned.  (

Addressed under Training Element.)

5) Employee involvement in the Prevention Program.  This is addressed on two levels.  First, refrigeration equipment operators participate in the planning and evaluation of the Prevention Programs (e.g., Process Hazard Analysis study team, writing and/or reviewing operating procedures, Incident Investigation team, etc.).  This involvement encourages ownership of the Prevention Program and positively affects the operators' day-to-day activities.  

Second, all Central City Cooling employees (direct hires and contract) at this facility receive ammonia awareness training.  Additionally, they have access to the RMP/PSM (CalARP) information.  These activities improve the overall safety of the employees. (Both levels are addressed under the Hazard Review and Training Elements)

6) Implementation of additional measures when changes are planned (procedural or mechanical).  These measures begin before any changes are made and may include a Process Hazard Analysis, operator training, and Process Safety Information updates plus other measures required by Central City Cooling's program.
 
If a mechanical change is required and for a change in maintenance contracts, Central City Cooling has a procedure for selecting a contractor based on the company's experience and safety history. Additionally, if welding, grinding, or other "Hot Work" occurs close to the refrigeration system, a Central City Cooling Hot Work permit is required.  The purpose of the permit and the associated Hot Work procedure is to minimize the possibility of a fire. 

7) Verification of Central City Cooling's compliance with the RMP/PSM (CalARP) program.  This self-audit process is an important tool to confirm whether each of the elements in the Prevention Program (and the Risk Management Program) has been implemented and properly documented by Central City Cooling personnel.  Central City Cooling has established a Management System procedure to address any shortcomings, whic

h the audit may find. (Addressed under Compliance Audit chapter.)   

8) Minimize employee injury and illness. (Addressed under the Injury and Illness Prevention Program)


FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
This is a new facility. There were no reportable ammonia releases at this facility during the last 5 years. 

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
This facility has trained personnel to implement the Emergency Response/Action Plan developed for this facility for flammables, fire, earthquake, hazardous materials and other emergencies. 

Facility personnel have coordinated with responding outside agencies such as Santa Barbara Fire. The facilities emergency action plan has been coordinated with the community plan which includes these agencies. 

The facility has coordinated with outside parties through the Hazardous Materials Business Plan. Facility personnel have exchanged data with local environmental authorities, fire and contractors who might assist during an emergency. In addition Fire Department personnel have toured the facility on several occasions to get a better understanding of the processes and the facilities during an emergency such as fire, earthquake and or a chemical release.

Detailed plans (emergency action plans) have been developed to assist responding facility personnel.  The facility has chosen to evacuate during all chemical emergencies. The facility will contact the contractor who can bring all areas (zones) under control within 20 minutes of any ammonia emergency or breakdown if personnel are on site.  Small releases can be brought under control immediately.  

The emergency plan is to gain access to the shut-down valves and switches for the equipment with the release.  If the controls or valves are within the ammonia release area the entire ammonia system may be shut down if appropriate. The appropriate shut down switches are identified on the equipment.  


The Federal and California Emergency Planning Regulations considered in this program include:
EPA's

Risk Management Plan
OSHA's Emergency Action and Response Plan
OSHA's Process Safety Standard
EPA's Emergency Planning and Community Right to Know
Contingency Plan
Hazardous Materials Business Plan (HMBP)                                                                                                                          CCR Title 8&19                                                                                                                                                   
                                                                                                                                                                                 PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
Employees, community safety, the environment and product care are primary concerns at this facility.  The prevention program has been created for this new facility.  A PHA studies was conducted at Central City Cooling and the study team made recommendations for additional safety.

The following list includes scheduled improvements to reduce accidental releases either in process or planned for at this time.
Add dial out for refrigeration failure to the control system
Label main isolation valves
Verify King Liquid Feed Valves close during system shut down.
Either purchase a scissors lift or add additional ladder access to roof.
Review ventilation code and verify system complies.
